channel.title: What Mastering Really Is
channel.description:
Hey, all,
It‚Äôs your friendly neighborhood audio engineer, Nick Elle.
I have been seeing a lot of people putting the tag ‚Äúremaster‚Äù on their tracks, but without actually knowing what a master actually is.
Well, I‚Äôm here to explain a bit.
In modern audio engineering, you have three parts: Recording, Mixing, and Mastering. But, for production, you really only have two parts: Mixing and Mastering, so I‚Äôll skip recording.
Mixing is basically what it sounds like. It‚Äôs mixing a lot of sounds together using tools like gain, EQ, compression, saturation, limiting, etc to create a full mix, which is the stereo (left and right channels) master audio. Pretty straight forward.
But, mastering is what gets most artists. Most of the time, they don‚Äôt know what it is.
Mastering is taking the mix (master audio) that just came from the mixing stage, and making it sound better. Using the same tools as mixing: EQ, compression, saturation (if needed), limiting, and some stereo widening, on the mix, you get a mastered song. It will sound much better than the original mix, resulting in a better sounding song.
And, a remaster is a mastering job done after the first one, in the event that the former wasn‚Äôt up to standards. For example, a remaster would be done by a modern audio engineer for a song made in the sixties, when audio wasn‚Äôt as pristine as it is now, to make it sound better.

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: GioMakyo
item.description:
And if you‚Äôre really well-established, you get about a dozen people to write it for you

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: GioMakyo
item.description:
The main benefit of mastering is to get a second set of ears, and somebody very skilled in the tools specific to mastering to ideally make your track better than you can do on your own. It‚Äôs like having an editor for writing, they find the stuff you don‚Äôt see. Also i find when composing entirely digitally in the box, like with Auxy, it really helps to have a run through a very high grade D/A system in mastering,

Read full topic

item.description:
I don‚Äôt know what y‚Äôall be doin‚Äô, but I use 32-bit WAVs.

Just kidding, I use 24. I don‚Äôt have storage space for 32, plus I don‚Äôt really need 32.

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
TheRealJFalc:

It does? Can you explain what you mean? So, like an additional 20db of audible range can be heard from the 24-bit depth?

16 bit audio has a dynamic range of about 96 dB (although it can be extended to around 120 with a few tricks).
24 bit audio has a dynamic range of about 144 dB.

edit: wikipedia -> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_range

Read full topic

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
iammane:

I usually export a 24-bit render from Grand Finale, but, I strongly suspect (wonder) if it even matters because I have a feeling my original output is 16-bit wave.

It wont make it sound better. It may make it sound worse, depending on how dither was handled.

Read full topic

item.description:
blakkaz:

It does give you an extra ~20db of headroom though.

It does? Can you explain what you mean? So, like an additional 20db of audible range can be heard from the 24-bit depth?

Read full topic

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
This all only really matters if your original source is also 24-bit, no? I am legit asking I don‚Äôt know. I usually export a 24-bit render from Grand Finale, but, I strongly suspect (wonder) if it even matters because I have a feeling my original output is 16-bit wave.

Kind of like, I could have a fiber connection feeding internet at my house, but if from the modem to the pole is CAT5 copper whatever then who cares.

Read full topic

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
If CloudBounce offered 16-bit for even less, I‚Äôd possibly take that option.
But at their current price, I‚Äôm happy to choose CloudBounce‚Äôs 24-bit (<¬£4) over Landr‚Äôs 16-bit (¬£9.99).

The ‚Äòextra quality‚Äô is just a neat bonus.

Generally speaking, I‚Äôm going to go with 24-bit for the same reason I always tend to avoid archiving in lossy formats. Just in case / peace of mind.

I can certainly understand the desire to go 24-bit* if you‚Äôre working really high-end.
(Auxy users aren‚Äôt likely to be operating in that area.)

 
* Some audiophiles will even bang on about how essential using 32-bit is.

Read full topic

I doubt anybody could hear the difference.
It does give you an extra ~20db of headroom though.

Read full topic

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
A note about paying $10 extra dollars for 24-bit WAV as opposed to 16-bit WAV‚Ä¶

https://www.image-line.com/support/flstudio_online_manual/html/app_audio.htm

Bits & Hz - Research has shown that for music distribution, 16 Bit @ 44.1 kHz (CD standard) is indistinguishable from 24 Bit @ 192 kHz in a sample of over 550 listeners1. In other words, more bits and higher bit-rates are not going to improve the ‚Äòquality‚Äô of your tracks.

Mixonline

The Emperor's New Sampling Rate

ARE CDS ACTUALLY GOOD ENOUGH?

I‚Äôd be interested to see your opinion of this.

Read full topic

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
I like Landr masters too, though I‚Äôve not yet coughed out for a WAV or even a 320 MP3 output.
Maybe I‚Äôll try Landr‚Äôs WAV outputs as a test.

Price also plays a part as 24-bit WAV outputs from CloudBounce across all packages is a fraction of the price of Landr.

As I‚Äôm not using a subscription package with either CloudBounce or Landr, I‚Äôm paying for WAVs on a pay-as-you-go / per-track basis.

I rarely consider a track of mine finished and release-ready/release quality, so I‚Äôm not keen on spending ¬£10-20 mastering a track that could well be tweaked later. At ¬£3.80, CloudBounce brings the price low enough that I wouldn‚Äôt mind having to redo auto-mastering if I make changes to a track.

 
Non-subscription, per-track prices‚Ä¶

 
Landr
320 kbps MP3 = ¬£4.99 / $4.99
16-bit WAV @ 44.1kHz = ¬£9.99 / $9.99
24-bit WAV @ 44.1kHz = ¬£19.99 / $19.99

(They don‚Äôt offer option to uprez a 16-bit WAV upload to 24-bit output)

 
CloudBounce
24-bit WAV @ 44.1kHz = ~¬£3.80 / $4.90 (incl. free 320 kbps MP3)

(No 16-bit output option. Everything is output at 24-bit, regardless of whether the file is 16, 24 or 32)

 
BandLab
320 kbps MP3 / 16-bit WAV / 24-bit WAV = Free (unlimited)

 
Note: Auxy outputs at 16-bit, but the (CloudBounce) uprezzing(?) didn‚Äôt seem to harm sound quality.

Read full topic

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Could be. Auxy renders are auto-mastered in-app with (what seems like) good, distortion-free mix levels. It just lacks oomph.

I‚Äôd put BandLab‚Äôs bass distortion purely down to their algo, as it should be smart enough not to push any frequencies into distortion levels.

It‚Äôs perhaps significant that it‚Äôs the only one I‚Äôm aware of that allows unlimited WAV auto-mastering for free. So perhaps it‚Äôs simply a less intelligent (i.e. cheaper, less investment) algo compared to those from services like LANDR and CloudBounce, which so far, have never pushed anything I‚Äôve tried into distortion.

Read full topic

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
Yep. I find on ALL basses in Auxy I need them at most 3/4 volume. Still good presence on earbuds, it‚Äôs good on the truck stereo but not overpowering everything else and sounds good in the Senns.

Read full topic

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
akabillposters:

I frequently get bass distortion when using BandLab‚Äôs (free) auto-mastering service.

I think this could be just Auxy prioritizing Bass and giving it a lot of volume. Most instruments have an objectively high amount of low end that needs to be cut out even with just a slight bump to the high pass. The only problem is that highpass is a global four-pole filter, so it‚Äôs very sharp in what it cuts out, while low pass is (usually) one banded and often varies by instrument. I remember @iammane saying that he needed to edit out low end so his car speakers didn‚Äôt break while playing auxy tracks before, but I may be mistaken.

More experimentation may need to be done, that‚Äôs for certain.

Read full topic

item.title: What Mastering Really Is
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Quick note on auto-mastering services‚Ä¶

I recently tried out Cloudbounce auto-mastering. Best I‚Äôve tried so far.
Just feels all round better balanced ‚Äì and there are many more fine-tuning/customisation options available compared to something like Landr (and it‚Äôs a lot cheaper per track than Landr).

I frequently get bass distortion when using BandLab‚Äôs (free) auto-mastering service. I‚Äôll keep using BandLab for quick n dirty review copies, but CloudBounce when I think it‚Äôs ready ($4.90/¬£3.75 for a 24-bit WAV master output).

cloudbounce.com

CloudBounce - Instant audio mastering that works. Just hear it.

Sound professional in minutes - master your audio files with CloudBounce.

Read full topic
